Addition Schemas.Name: P2W
Addition Schemas.Comments: The whole is equal to the sum of two parts.

Addition Schemas.Name: P3W
Addition Schemas.Comments: The whole is equal to the sum of three parts.

Addition Schemas.Name: P4W
Addition Schemas.Comments: The whole is equal to the sum of four parts.

Addition Schemas.Name: P5W
Addition Schemas.Equation: W = PA + PB + PC + PD + PE
Addition Schemas.Comments: The whole is equal to the sum of five parts.

Addition Schemas.Name: Compare
Addition Schemas.Comments: The whole is equal to the sum of five parts.

Addition Schemas.Name: Tailwind
Addition Schemas.Comments: If a vehicle travels through a moving medium (e.g., airplane in wind; boat on river current), and the vehicle is travelling the same direction as the medium (i.e., with a tailwind for the airplane; downstream for the boat), then slots are: GroundSpeed is the rate of the vehicle relative to land, AirSpeed is the rate of the vehicle relative to the medium, Windspeed is the rate of the medium (i.e., wind’s speed; river current’s speed).

Addition Schemas.Name: Headwind
Addition Schemas.Comments: If a vehicle travels through a moving medium (e.g., airplane in wind; boat on river current), and the vehicle is travelling in the opposite direction to the medium (i.e., with a headwind for the airplane; upstream for the boat), then slots are: GroundSpeed is the rate of the vehicle relative to the land, AirSpeed is the rate of the vehicle relative to the medium (i.e., how fast the plane or boat travels in still air or still water), WindSpeed is the rate of the medium (i.e., wind’s speed; river current’s speed)

Multiplication Schemas.Name: DRT
Multiplication Schemas.Comments: This is used for any problem that talks about a rate per unit of time, such as miles per hour, feet per second, gallons per hour, jobs done per hour, pizzas eaten per minute, etc. The slots are: Rate:  The amount of X per unit of time, Distance:  The amount of X accumulated over the given time, Time:  The amount of time.

Multiplication Schemas.Name: Unit Cost
Multiplication Schemas.Comments: If the total cost (or other quantity) of a set of object is mentioned along with the cost per object, then use this.  Used for any problem talking about rate per object, e.g.,  Calories per candy, weight per car, nuts per tree.   The slots are: TotalCost is the total cost of the set of objects, NumberUnits is the number of objects, UnitCost is the cost per object.

Multiplication Schemas.Name: Mixture
Multiplication Schemas.Comments: If a drink is composed of water and alcohol (or any substance is composed of a filler and an active ingredient, e.g., acid in a water solution, fat in sausage), then Amount of Ingredient is the amount of alcohol, measured by weight or volume, Amount of Solution is the total amount of the drink, measured by weight or volume, Proportion of I to S is the proportion (converted from a percentage or proof) of alcohol in the drink.

Multiplication Schemas.Name: Invert
Multiplication Schemas.Comments: Sometimes you need to invert a quantity in order to use it in a calculation.
